href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/finding-solidarity-in-an-effort-to-vaccinate-the-world">Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance</a><em>; </em><a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/modernas-path-to-vaccine-innovation-a-talk-with-ceo-stephane-bancel">Moderna</a><em>; and </em><a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/pfizers-mix-of-science-and-grit-alters-the-course-of-its-covid-19-response">Pfizer</a><em>.</em></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Fhealthcare%20systems%20and%20services%2Four%20insights%2Fafricas%20plan%20for%20a%20continent%20wide%20pandemic%20recovery%2Fafricas-plan-for-a-continent-wide-pandemic-recovery-final.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="africas-plan-for-a-continent-wide-pandemic-recovery-final" data-layer-report-name="africas-plan-for-a-continent-wide-pandemic-recovery-final>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (6 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>Africa has had a long history</strong> of disproportionate struggle with deadly viruses. The COVID-19 crisis seems to have further illuminated the need for the continent to have a coordinated approach to meet pandemic threats head-on. Dr. John Nkengasong, the first-ever director of the Africa CDC, is a strong believer of a joint continental strategy being the “North Star” on which to guide pandemic response.</p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About this series: <em>COVID-19 vaccines: The road to recovery and beyond</em></div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This interview is part of the series <em>COVID-19 vaccines: The road to recovery and beyond</em>. By drawing on the experience of private- and public-sector experts across a wide range of perspectives—from vaccine innovation to manufacturing, distribution, and accessibility—we aim to help leaders navigate recovery efforts for the COVID-19 pandemic and share some of the lessons they’ve learned to combat the pandemic and support the future of vaccines. Articles in the series include interviews with the heads of top global health organizations, government agencies, and vaccine manufacturers. For example:</p>
<ul>
    <li><a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/africas-plan-for-a-continent-wide-pandemic-recovery">Africa CDC: Africa’s plan for a continent-wide pandemic recovery</a></li>
    <li><a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/accelerating-pandemic-response-efforts-an-interview-with-cepis-richard-hatchett">Accelerating pandemic response efforts: An interview with CEPI’s Richard Hatchett</a> </li>
    <li><a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/finding-solidarity-in-an-effort-to-vaccinate-the-world">Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance: Finding solidarity in an effort to vaccinate the world</a></li>
    <li><a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/modernas-path-to-vaccine-innovation-a-talk-with-ceo-stephane-bancel">Moderna’s path to vaccine innovation: A talk with CEO Stéphane Bancel</a></li>
    <li><a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/pfizers-mix-of-science-and-grit-alters-the-course-of-its-covid-19-response">Pfizer’s mix of science and grit alters the course of its COVID-19 response</a></li>
</ul>
<p>Along with public-health authorities, we recognize that vaccination is critical to combating infectious diseases, and we are committed to the urgent effort of bringing an end to the COVID-19 pandemic and transforming the future of immunization.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Some groups of countries have long had a centralized public-health unit, but the Africa CDC is the first of its kind in Africa. Established in 2016, the Africa CDC was officially launched under the African Union (AU) in 2017 to support the health systems of 55 member states and directly respond to disease threats.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d8a7db45-87e8-4a0a-8579-e7d6f653a7f9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d8a7db45-87e8-4a0a-8579-e7d6f653a7f9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“About us,” Africa CDC, accessed June 24, 2021, africacdc.org. </span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Since the COVID-19 pandemic began, Africa has experienced more than five million cases and more than 140,000 deaths,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e33c05cc-aed6-44fa-8c93-6e47ace4bc4b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e33c05cc-aed6-44fa-8c93-6e47ace4bc4b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Number of coronavirus (COVID-19) deaths in the African continent as of June 24, 2021, by country,” Statista, June 24, 2021, statista.com.</span></span></span></a></span> heightening the relevance of the Africa CDC and giving it major prominence. Leading the fast mobilization of heads of state around a continent-wide response to the pandemic, the Africa CDC is setting the groundwork for the first public-health order in Africa, possibly changing the face of its public-health landscape for a long time to come.</p>
<p>Since Africa relies heavily on imported vaccines to beat COVID-19 and most other infectious diseases, Dr. Nkengasong is also an advocate for homegrown manufacturing. In a virtual conference held in April 2021 by the Africa CDC, there was an aspiration set to manufacture 60 percent of the continent’s needed vaccines locally by 2040.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="509050db-4376-4318-9479-080bcd1dc1f9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="509050db-4376-4318-9479-080bcd1dc1f9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sara Jerving, “AU launches Partnership for African Vaccine Manufacturing,” Devex, April 14, 2021, devex.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Nkengasong thinks that the COVID-19 crisis may accelerate that goal.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-o-sm-left-span Image_mck-c-image__fhx5v"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Image_mck-c-image__img-container__JusDB"><img alt="Africa’s plan for a continent-wide pandemic recovery" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/africas%20plan%20for%20a%20continent%20wide%20pandemic%20recovery/drnkengasong-hero-1536x1536.jpg?cq=50&mw=767&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-9 mdc-u-mt-3 Image_mck-c-image__description__nsDz3"><div>Dr. John Nkengasong</div></div></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">Africa’s plan for a continent-wide pandemic recovery</div></div>
<p>Dr. Nkengasong took some time to speak with McKinsey’s Sunny Sun on what it will take to deploy a continent-wide vaccine rollout, increase vaccine manufacturing within Africa, and enhance coordination across borders further. The outcomes could help Africa better control its response to COVID-19 and any future infectious diseases and improve the health security of the continent. What follows is an edited excerpt of their conversation.</p>
<p><strong>McKinsey: </strong>You talk about a continent-wide approach to combating COVID-19. How has the creation of the Africa CDC driven this approach? What challenges did the pandemic present and what was the response to them?</p>
<p><strong>John Nkengasong: </strong>The Africa CDC is the backbone of the continent-wide mobilization among AU member states. I’ve always maintained that its creation was one of the greatest innovations of African leadership. Members watched in disbelief as the 2014 to 2016 West Africa Ebola epidemic threatened the health and economic security of 1.2 billion people on the continent. It ultimately claimed 11,299 lives.</p>
<p>By January 2019, the Africa CDC had responded to nine disease outbreaks in seven AU member states. During the 2018 to 2019 Ebola outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo and Uganda, 48 healthcare experts were sent out to train over 820 local health and community workers on infection prevention and cross-border screenings.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cbee725d-0349-4767-a182-43e860c09459"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cbee725d-0349-4767-a182-43e860c09459" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“How would Africa have managed COVID-19 without the Africa CDC? The role of China,” China-Africa Project, April 9, 2021, chinaafricaproject.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Thankfully, this framework was in place—because Ebola was at no imaginable level equivalent to what we’re facing with COVID-19.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>People often think of Africa as a homogeneous block of people, which is not the case. Coordinating efforts and bringing 55 member states into alignment is a challenge in itself. But we faced it head-on because we had no choice. The first cases of COVID-19 in Africa were reported in Egypt on February 14, 2020. Within one week, we were able to convene an emergency meeting with most of the ministers of health from across the continent in the Ethiopian capital of Addis Ababa.</p>
<p>When leaders left Addis Ababa on February 22, there was clarity of action on what each member state would do when they got home and COVID-19 hit—because it wasn’t a matter of<em> if </em>but <em>when </em>it would strike throughout the continent. This joint continental strategy became the North Star on which to guide the pandemic response across Africa and still underpins our ability to respond to COVID-19 today.</p>
<!-- -->
<p><strong>McKinsey:</strong> The COVID-19 crisis has likely strengthened support for Africa’s new public-health order. Can you talk about the order’s different components and goals?</p>
<p><strong>John Nkengasong: </strong>The concept behind a new public-health order for Africa is the recognition that health is central to our developmental process—that infectious diseases are critical and can easily undermine our agenda.</p>
<p>There are four key elements that make up Africa’s public-health order. One is strengthening our own public-health institutions with an empowered Africa CDC that connects with the national public-health institutes in all 55 member states. This creates a health-security apparatus that can consistently respond to disease outbreaks. Two is the need for local manufacturing of diagnostics, pharmaceuticals, and vaccines. With the COVID-19 crisis, we had no diagnostics or vaccines. The continent was literally exposed. Three is a competent public-health workforce. Without it, there’s absolutely nothing we can achieve in the spirit of strengthening our health defenses on the continent. And four is engaging with the private sector for innovations that can drive our health- and economic-security agendas.</p>

<p>What the COVID-19 pandemic has done is bring the new public-health order to life much faster, since issues we were discussing in theory, such as a severe lack of manufacturing, the desperation over diagnostics, the slow vaccine acquisition, and shortage of health workforce, have now come to the fore. For example, our ability to deploy health responders has been ad hoc at best. In April 2020, we had to hire a military plane in Cameroon, take it to the Democratic Republic of Congo, transport 28 health responders, and drop them in Niger, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, and Mali. We had to pull epidemiologists from the Ebola response in North Kivu. Clearly, we can’t guarantee the health security of a large continent of 1.2 billion people like this. We need a more comprehensive strategy.</p>
<p><strong>McKinsey: </strong>How has the response to COVID-19 shifted from the first wave to the most recent developments?</p>
<!-- -->
<p><strong>John Nkengasong: </strong>When we look at the surge of cases in India in April, you have to factor in the prospect of that happening in Africa, which is a real concern. The way we can prepare ourselves is to revise our strategy around the communities: supporting and educating them on ownership, engagement, and leadership.</p>
<p>During the first wave of COVID-19, the focus was on testing. But now, we’ve adjusted our strategy to better monitor, prevent, and treat the disease. Based on learnings from India, monitoring means that we look at how we increase our ability to track variants more rigorously on the continent. Monitoring also means bettering surveillance, looking more carefully at the communities, finding any pockets of infection—and squashing them. We are not in the same situation that India was in, but the time to prepare—such as working to scale up our oxygen supply—is now.</p>
<p>To better support our strategy, we’ve also created the African Medical Supplies Platform to supply countries with vaccines, along with the equipment needed to maintain them, and to help governments with strategies on how to distribute limited vaccine supplies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="46a7cae9-d41d-41b0-a717-1fd79b676dcb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="46a7cae9-d41d-41b0-a717-1fd79b676dcb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“How would Africa have managed COVID-19 without the Africa CDC? The role of China,” China-Africa Project, April 9, 2021, chinaafricaproject.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>But it’s not just about providing the country with the supplies to properly store and handle vaccines, such as a cold-chain setup and vaccination accessories. You also need to pay attention to risk communication throughout the health event to encourage informed decision making and maintain trust. Deploying a vaccination plan if the communities aren’t fully engaged and the risk communication is not fully addressed is not ideal. The Africa CDC has put out a simple equation: “Vaccines plus vaccinations equal saved lives and economies.”</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>The Africa CDC has put out a simple equation: ‘Vaccines plus vaccinations equal saved lives and economies.’</p></blockquote></div>
<p><strong>McKinsey: </strong>On the vaccine front, how would you define the access challenges that exist in Africa? And how are you working to remedy them through partnerships?</p>
<p><strong>John Nkengasong: </strong>Access to COVID-19 vaccines in Africa has been sluggish at best. If we continue at this pace, we will not achieve the Africa CDC target of vaccinating 60 percent of Africa’s population by the end of 2022. Our hope is that some countries that have acquired a lot of COVID-19 vaccines will donate surplus doses to African nations sooner rather than later.</p>
<p>In the area of vaccination acquisition, there’s COVAX, managed by WHO, Gavi, and CEPI. We have also established the African Vaccine Acquisition Task Team because COVAX will only cover 20 to 30 percent of our needs, and we need to vaccinate 60 percent of our population. That’s a 30-percentage-point gap that needs to be filled. There are also individual, bilateral, and multilateral deals that various African countries are engaged in.</p>
<p>We also need more partnerships to help with building vaccination centers—which includes redesigning workflows, repurposing existing hospitals and facilities, and setting up clinics within arenas—so we can vaccinate at scale and with speed. That said, the World Bank and other institutions and foundations are working with African countries to allocate additional resources. We are beginning to see a whole coalition of different partners coming in to support individual member states to roll out vaccinations.</p>
<p><strong>McKinsey: </strong>Another pandemic response could be the manufacturing of domestic vaccines for COVID-19 and other infectious diseases. What would it take for Africa to manufacture its own vaccines?</p>
<!-- -->
<p><strong>John Nkengasong: </strong>In a sense, you could say we are at war with the pandemic. And if we are at war, we need to use everything we have. Africa has the capacity and the ability to vaccinate. For instance, in the middle of this crisis, Ethiopia has been able to vaccinate 12 million children with measles vaccines. It is doable; we just need the vaccines. So we need to look at how we can manufacture vaccines from home.</p>
<p>In the spring of 2021, we held a summit with some of the top researchers, business leaders, civil-society groups, and heads of state on how to bring vaccine manufacturing to Africa. We vowed to achieve an ambitious aspiration for the continent to manufacture at least 60 percent of our routinely used vaccines by 2040.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9d26c0a6-6d3b-444e-b3ea-8a7ac3109799"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9d26c0a6-6d3b-444e-b3ea-8a7ac3109799" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Africa’s vaccines revolution must have research at its core,” <em>Nature</em>, April 2021, Volume 592, Number 7,855, pp. 487–88, nature.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Currently, we only manufacture 1 percent. A continent that holds 1.2 billion people shouldn’t be having to import 99 percent of its vaccines. We need to apply ourselves in a very deliberate manner in order to achieve that goal.</p>
<p>It starts by mobilizing enough financial resources to make manufacturing happen on the continent, which is an uphill climb. We need to look inward at the African Development Bank or Afreximbank and see these efforts as an investment in our people and in the next generation of Africans. When the history of the COVID-19 pandemic is written, I want Africa to be remembered for doing the right thing.</p>
<p>Then we need to get the right partnerships for intellectual-property transfer on the continent so that we can begin to develop and achieve these ambitious vaccine-manufacturing targets. What’s also important is strengthening our regulatory processes on the continent and launching groups like the African Medicines Agency, which contributes to the approved regulation of medicines in a timely fashion.</p>
<p>Probably the most critical aspect in the area of manufacturing is the launch of the Partnerships for African Vaccine Manufacturing in April 2021 by the AU to drive the agenda on vaccine manufacturing for the continent. It will also support five regional production sites over the next ten to 15 years, secure financial partnerships, and work on developing African universities as hubs for vaccine research and development.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b213e967-0c36-4860-9624-94fe1db2e766"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b213e967-0c36-4860-9624-94fe1db2e766" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“AU launches partnership,” 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>In the history of infectious diseases, vaccines have always been central in turning the tide. Africa should learn from this experience in that you cannot mortgage your health security to external factors. Africa needs to be in full control of its vaccine security.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Coronavirus Vaccines Progress: What’s Next?" src="/~/media/mckinsey/featured%20insights/coronavirus%20vaccines%20progress/vaccines-1536x1536.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Coronavirus vaccines progress: What’s next?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/featured-insights/coronavirus-vaccines-progress" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the articles</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>McKinsey: </strong>As you lead the continent through the COVID-19 pandemic, what have been your biggest challenges to date? And what have you learned so far?</p>
<p><strong>John Nkengasong:</strong> When working hard to supply countries with a vaccine in a timely fashion, the greatest challenge for me has been managing the gap between knowing what we need and not having what we need. For instance, in 2020, we knew that the central pillar to responding to any infectious disease was acquisition of diagnostics. But we didn’t have the diagnostics. It was very frustrating because it’s impossible to fight a disease that we can’t diagnose. Identifying the gaps and finding the necessary supplies has been extremely challenging.</p>
<p>Another tough situation is when countries are looking to you to tell them where to get the vaccines. It’s been heartbreaking to hear countries say to me at times, “John, we have the money to buy the vaccines. We have the money to buy the diagnostics. Just tell us where to go get them.” And you’re sitting there as the leader of a public-health agency, and you truly don’t know the answer.</p>
<p>But it’s also been very rewarding to see the countries that have expressed real solidarity, coming together to work across geographic areas. For instance, there’s the cross-country work ECOWAS [Economic Community of West African States] is doing, led by Professor Stanley Okolo, on evidence-based health policies and how they are vital in achieving continued improvement in health outcomes.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ce43dd6d-1fd1-4583-92c1-999806bd452f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ce43dd6d-1fd1-4583-92c1-999806bd452f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Issiaka Sombié et al., “How does the West African Health Organisation (WAHO) contribute to the evidence based decision-making and practice during COVID-19 pandemic in ECOWAS region?,” <em>Pan African Medical Journal</em>, October 2020, Volume 37, Supplement 1, p. 20, panafrican-med-journal.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Also, Nigeria has been a strong advocate for vaccine equity, led by the director general of the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control, Chikwe Ihekweazu, who’s committed to multilateral deals with WHO, COVAX, and the AU to get vaccines not only for his country but also across the continent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6ae95061-72ac-4ab0-b7e1-a5de277e7d06"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6ae95061-72ac-4ab0-b7e1-a5de277e7d06" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Stephanie Nebehay and Michael Shields, “Nigeria expects first 4 million coronavirus vaccine doses from COVAX next week: WHO,” Reuters, February 26, 2021, reuters.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Examples like these have encouraged us to say that we can truly implement our new public-health order, which hinges on strengthening our own regional- and public-health agencies and institutions across the continent. I don’t think there’s any moment in the history of fighting diseases in Africa that has seen the same degree of coordination, collaboration, and cooperation as fighting the COVID-19 pandemic has.</p>

<hr>
<p>This article was edited by Astrid Sandoval, an executive editor in the London office.</p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-screen-only"><div type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Africas plan for a continent wide pandemic recovery","displayName":"Africas plan for a continent wide pandemic recovery","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"7fb297d3-10a6-44db-b409-54c12858f04d","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":3,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Africa\u0026rsquo;s plan for a continent-wide pandemic recovery"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Africa\u0026rsquo;s plan for a continent-wide pandemic recovery with African Union"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Dr. John Nkengasong, director of Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC), explains what\u0026rsquo;s needed to tackle COVID-19 across the continent."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-08-13T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview is part of \u003c/em\u003eCOVID-19 vaccines: The road to recovery and beyond\u003cem\u003e, a series that includes a broad array of voices leading the historic global effort to develop, distribute, and provide equitable access to COVID-19 vaccines, including the \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/africas-plan-for-a-continent-wide-pandemic-recovery\"\u003eAfrica CDC\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e; \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/accelerating-pandemic-response-efforts-an-interview-with-cepis-richard-hatchett\"\u003eCEPI\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e; \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/finding-solidarity-in-an-effort-to-vaccinate-the-world\"\u003eGavi, the Vaccine Alliance\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e; \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/modernas-path-to-vaccine-innovation-a-talk-with-ceo-stephane-bancel\"\u003eModerna\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e; and \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/pfizers-mix-of-science-and-grit-alters-the-course-of-its-covid-19-response\"\u003ePfizer\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAfrica has had a long history\u003c/strong\u003e of disproportionate struggle with deadly viruses. The COVID-19 crisis seems to have further illuminated the need for the continent to have a coordinated approach to meet pandemic threats head-on. Dr. John Nkengasong, the first-ever director of the Africa CDC, is a strong believer of a joint continental strategy being the \u0026ldquo;North Star\u0026rdquo; on which to guide pandemic response.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eSome groups of countries have long had a centralized public-health unit, but the Africa CDC is the first of its kind in Africa. Established in 2016, the Africa CDC was officially launched under the African Union (AU) in 2017 to support the health systems of 55 member states and directly respond to disease threats.[[Footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSince the COVID-19 pandemic began, Africa has experienced more than five million cases and more than 140,000 deaths,[[Footnote 2]] heightening the relevance of the Africa CDC and giving it major prominence. Leading the fast mobilization of heads of state around a continent-wide response to the pandemic, the Africa CDC is setting the groundwork for the first public-health order in Africa, possibly changing the face of its public-health landscape for a long time to come.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSince Africa relies heavily on imported vaccines to beat COVID-19 and most other infectious diseases, Dr. Nkengasong is also an advocate for homegrown manufacturing. In a virtual conference held in April 2021 by the Africa CDC, there was an aspiration set to manufacture 60 percent of the continent\u0026rsquo;s needed vaccines locally by 2040.[[Footnote 3]] Nkengasong thinks that the COVID-19 crisis may accelerate that goal.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Image 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eDr. Nkengasong took some time to speak with McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Sunny Sun on what it will take to deploy a continent-wide vaccine rollout, increase vaccine manufacturing within Africa, and enhance coordination across borders further. The outcomes could help Africa better control its response to COVID-19 and any future infectious diseases and improve the health security of the continent. What follows is an edited excerpt of their conversation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey: \u003c/strong\u003eYou talk about a continent-wide approach to combating COVID-19. How has the creation of the Africa CDC driven this approach? What challenges did the pandemic present and what was the response to them?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohn Nkengasong: \u003c/strong\u003eThe Africa CDC is the backbone of the continent-wide mobilization among AU member states. I\u0026rsquo;ve always maintained that its creation was one of the greatest innovations of African leadership. Members watched in disbelief as the 2014 to 2016 West Africa Ebola epidemic threatened the health and economic security of 1.2 billion people on the continent. It ultimately claimed 11,299 lives.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy January 2019, the Africa CDC had responded to nine disease outbreaks in seven AU member states. During the 2018 to 2019 Ebola outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo and Uganda, 48 healthcare experts were sent out to train over 820 local health and community workers on infection prevention and cross-border screenings.[[Footnote 4]] Thankfully, this framework was in place\u0026mdash;because Ebola was at no imaginable level equivalent to what we\u0026rsquo;re facing with COVID-19.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Video 3]]\n\u003cp\u003ePeople often think of Africa as a homogeneous block of people, which is not the case. Coordinating efforts and bringing 55 member states into alignment is a challenge in itself. But we faced it head-on because we had no choice. The first cases of COVID-19 in Africa were reported in Egypt on February 14, 2020. Within one week, we were able to convene an emergency meeting with most of the ministers of health from across the continent in the Ethiopian capital of Addis Ababa.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen leaders left Addis Ababa on February 22, there was clarity of action on what each member state would do when they got home and COVID-19 hit\u0026mdash;because it wasn\u0026rsquo;t a matter of\u003cem\u003e if \u003c/em\u003ebut \u003cem\u003ewhen \u003c/em\u003eit would strike throughout the continent. This joint continental strategy became the North Star on which to guide the pandemic response across Africa and still underpins our ability to respond to COVID-19 today.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey:\u003c/strong\u003e The COVID-19 crisis has likely strengthened support for Africa\u0026rsquo;s new public-health order. Can you talk about the order\u0026rsquo;s different components and goals?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohn Nkengasong: \u003c/strong\u003eThe concept behind a new public-health order for Africa is the recognition that health is central to our developmental process\u0026mdash;that infectious diseases are critical and can easily undermine our agenda.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are four key elements that make up Africa\u0026rsquo;s public-health order. One is strengthening our own public-health institutions with an empowered Africa CDC that connects with the national public-health institutes in all 55 member states. This creates a health-security apparatus that can consistently respond to disease outbreaks. Two is the need for local manufacturing of diagnostics, pharmaceuticals, and vaccines. With the COVID-19 crisis, we had no diagnostics or vaccines. The continent was literally exposed. Three is a competent public-health workforce. Without it, there\u0026rsquo;s absolutely nothing we can achieve in the spirit of strengthening our health defenses on the continent. And four is engaging with the private sector for innovations that can drive our health- and economic-security agendas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eWhat the COVID-19 pandemic has done is bring the new public-health order to life much faster, since issues we were discussing in theory, such as a severe lack of manufacturing, the desperation over diagnostics, the slow vaccine acquisition, and shortage of health workforce, have now come to the fore. For example, our ability to deploy health responders has been ad hoc at best. In April 2020, we had to hire a military plane in Cameroon, take it to the Democratic Republic of Congo, transport 28 health responders, and drop them in Niger, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, and Mali. We had to pull epidemiologists from the Ebola response in North Kivu. Clearly, we can\u0026rsquo;t guarantee the health security of a large continent of 1.2 billion people like this. We need a more comprehensive strategy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey: \u003c/strong\u003eHow has the response to COVID-19 shifted from the first wave to the most recent developments?\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Video 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohn Nkengasong: \u003c/strong\u003eWhen we look at the surge of cases in India in April, you have to factor in the prospect of that happening in Africa, which is a real concern. The way we can prepare ourselves is to revise our strategy around the communities: supporting and educating them on ownership, engagement, and leadership.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDuring the first wave of COVID-19, the focus was on testing. But now, we\u0026rsquo;ve adjusted our strategy to better monitor, prevent, and treat the disease. Based on learnings from India, monitoring means that we look at how we increase our ability to track variants more rigorously on the continent. Monitoring also means bettering surveillance, looking more carefully at the communities, finding any pockets of infection\u0026mdash;and squashing them. We are not in the same situation that India was in, but the time to prepare\u0026mdash;such as working to scale up our oxygen supply\u0026mdash;is now.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo better support our strategy, we\u0026rsquo;ve also created the African Medical Supplies Platform to supply countries with vaccines, along with the equipment needed to maintain them, and to help governments with strategies on how to distribute limited vaccine supplies.[[Footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut it\u0026rsquo;s not just about providing the country with the supplies to properly store and handle vaccines, such as a cold-chain setup and vaccination accessories. You also need to pay attention to risk communication throughout the health event to encourage informed decision making and maintain trust. Deploying a vaccination plan if the communities aren\u0026rsquo;t fully engaged and the risk communication is not fully addressed is not ideal. The Africa CDC has put out a simple equation: \u0026ldquo;Vaccines plus vaccinations equal saved lives and economies.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Pullquote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey: \u003c/strong\u003eOn the vaccine front, how would you define the access challenges that exist in Africa? And how are you working to remedy them through partnerships?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohn Nkengasong: \u003c/strong\u003eAccess to COVID-19 vaccines in Africa has been sluggish at best. If we continue at this pace, we will not achieve the Africa CDC target of vaccinating 60 percent of Africa\u0026rsquo;s population by the end of 2022. Our hope is that some countries that have acquired a lot of COVID-19 vaccines will donate surplus doses to African nations sooner rather than later.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the area of vaccination acquisition, there\u0026rsquo;s COVAX, managed by WHO, Gavi, and CEPI. We have also established the African Vaccine Acquisition Task Team because COVAX will only cover 20 to 30 percent of our needs, and we need to vaccinate 60 percent of our population. That\u0026rsquo;s a 30-percentage-point gap that needs to be filled. There are also individual, bilateral, and multilateral deals that various African countries are engaged in.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe also need more partnerships to help with building vaccination centers\u0026mdash;which includes redesigning workflows, repurposing existing hospitals and facilities, and setting up clinics within arenas\u0026mdash;so we can vaccinate at scale and with speed. That said, the World Bank and other institutions and foundations are working with African countries to allocate additional resources. We are beginning to see a whole coalition of different partners coming in to support individual member states to roll out vaccinations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey: \u003c/strong\u003eAnother pandemic response could be the manufacturing of domestic vaccines for COVID-19 and other infectious diseases. What would it take for Africa to manufacture its own vaccines?\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Video 2]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohn Nkengasong: \u003c/strong\u003eIn a sense, you could say we are at war with the pandemic. And if we are at war, we need to use everything we have. Africa has the capacity and the ability to vaccinate. For instance, in the middle of this crisis, Ethiopia has been able to vaccinate 12 million children with measles vaccines. It is doable; we just need the vaccines. So we need to look at how we can manufacture vaccines from home.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the spring of 2021, we held a summit with some of the top researchers, business leaders, civil-society groups, and heads of state on how to bring vaccine manufacturing to Africa. We vowed to achieve an ambitious aspiration for the continent to manufacture at least 60 percent of our routinely used vaccines by 2040.[[Footnote 6]] Currently, we only manufacture 1 percent. A continent that holds 1.2\u0026nbsp;billion people shouldn\u0026rsquo;t be having to import 99 percent of its vaccines. We need to apply ourselves in a very deliberate manner in order to achieve that goal.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt starts by mobilizing enough financial resources to make manufacturing happen on the continent, which is an uphill climb. We need to look inward at the African Development Bank or Afreximbank and see these efforts as an investment in our people and in the next generation of Africans. When the history of the COVID-19 pandemic is written, I want Africa to be remembered for doing the right thing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThen we need to get the right partnerships for intellectual-property transfer on the continent so that we can begin to develop and achieve these ambitious vaccine-manufacturing targets. What\u0026rsquo;s also important is strengthening our regulatory processes on the continent and launching groups like the African Medicines Agency, which contributes to the approved regulation of medicines in a timely fashion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eProbably the most critical aspect in the area of manufacturing is the launch of the Partnerships for African Vaccine Manufacturing in April 2021 by the AU to drive the agenda on vaccine manufacturing for the continent. It will also support five regional production sites over the next ten to 15 years, secure financial partnerships, and work on developing African universities as hubs for vaccine research and development.[[Footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the history of infectious diseases, vaccines have always been central in turning the tide. Africa should learn from this experience in that you cannot mortgage your health security to external factors. Africa needs to be in full control of its vaccine security.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey: \u003c/strong\u003eAs you lead the continent through the COVID-19 pandemic, what have been your biggest challenges to date? And what have you learned so far?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJohn Nkengasong:\u003c/strong\u003e When working hard to supply countries with a vaccine in a timely fashion, the greatest challenge for me has been managing the gap between knowing what we need and not having what we need. For instance, in 2020, we knew that the central pillar to responding to any infectious disease was acquisition of diagnostics. But we didn\u0026rsquo;t have the diagnostics. It was very frustrating because it\u0026rsquo;s impossible to fight a disease that we can\u0026rsquo;t diagnose. Identifying the gaps and finding the necessary supplies has been extremely challenging.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother tough situation is when countries are looking to you to tell them where to get the vaccines. It\u0026rsquo;s been heartbreaking to hear countries say to me at times, \u0026ldquo;John, we have the money to buy the vaccines. We have the money to buy the diagnostics. Just tell us where to go get them.\u0026rdquo; And you\u0026rsquo;re sitting there as the leader of a public-health agency, and you truly don\u0026rsquo;t know the answer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut it\u0026rsquo;s also been very rewarding to see the countries that have expressed real solidarity, coming together to work across geographic areas. For instance, there\u0026rsquo;s the cross-country work ECOWAS [Economic Community of West African States] is doing, led by Professor Stanley Okolo, on evidence-based health policies and how they are vital in achieving continued improvement in health outcomes.[[Footnote 8]] Also, Nigeria has been a strong advocate for vaccine equity, led by the director general of the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control, Chikwe Ihekweazu, who\u0026rsquo;s committed to multilateral deals with WHO, COVAX, and the AU to get vaccines not only for his country but also across the continent.[[Footnote 9]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExamples like these have encouraged us to say that we can truly implement our new public-health order, which hinges on strengthening our own regional- and public-health agencies and institutions across the continent. I don\u0026rsquo;t think there\u0026rsquo;s any moment in the history of fighting diseases in Africa that has seen the same degree of coordination, collaboration, and cooperation as fighting the COVID-19 pandemic has.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis content is provided \u0026ldquo;as is\u0026rdquo; solely for informational purposes. It is not legal, health, or safety advice. Organizations\nshould engage their own experts to ensure that any adopted measures are compliant with applicable laws and standards in their jurisdictions. The opinions expressed by individuals or organizations are their own and do not reflect the views or opinions of McKinsey.
